Message.Title: The vacation president
Message.Msg: Those who criticize the cost of Obama’s Christmas vacation don’t want you to know that George W. Bush spent at least $20 million taxpayer dollars just on flights to his ranch in Crawford. . Not only did Bush spend more days on vacation than any other president, but he used Air Force One more often while on vacation than any other president. During Bush’s two terms, the cost of operating Air Force One ranged from $56,800 to $68,000 an hour. Bush used Air Force One 77 times to go to his ranch in Crawford, TX. Using the low end cost of $56,800, Media Matters calculated that each trip to Crawford cost taxpayers $259,687 each time, and $20 million total for Bush’s ranch flights. If cost of the flight was the only expense involved to taxpayers Bush’s vacations would still seem rather economical, but there is more, much more. The cost of transporting and accommodating staff, media, friends and family is not included in Bush’s vacation numbers. While at the ranch he then used AF 1 as his personal taxi to other events. Obama and his family vacations are a drop in the bucket relative to what both Bush and Reagan cost in vacations.

Message.Title: this week, easter
Message.Msg: This week on Easter Sunday 2013 Very few sponsors this week—GE and oil/gas pressure group, manufacturers of several medicines/drugs, and BP with its usual gulf care message. GOP representative Peter King did mention worry that North Korea might ‘box itself in”. PANEL members, no g f Will this week, felt the Supreme Court may be seeking some way to deal with the “Proposition 8” issue, to avoid a wide ranging response. Matthew Dowd, GOP operative, feels the court is out of touch with the national mood re gay matters; Newark Mayor Cory Booker fears creation of a “second class citizenship” re the marriage matter’ Nation magazine editor K Vandenheuvel says “marriage equality has won”, while Dowd points out changes in marriage and sexual considerations have evolved significantly over 2,000 years—women, for example, were thought of as “property’. Touching upon immigration, Rep King proclaimed “border security exists” a weekend deal on immigration, meaning wages, numbers, etc, seems to have been reached. Religion—Cardinal Timothy Dolan says Francis I stresses “simplicity and service” within Biblical teachings, with a segue into “one man, one woman, children” being the Biblical precept. He fears society says “me, myself, and I”, the church instead “our”. In discussion of religion in society, a different panel had members asserting that religion is a matter of identity, not practice, and that the idea of concern for “the common good” seems less prevalent nowadays. Three in their twenties made the ultimate sacrifice in Afghanistan, from Calif, Indians, and Kentucky.. Tactful Eastertime wishes were voiced.

Message.Title: Libor Suits by Bondholders Tossed Over Lack of Damages
Message.Msg: Mar 31, 2013 4:00 PM PT Banks including Bank of America Corp., Barclays Plc (BARC) and JPMorgan Chase & Co. (JPM) won dismissal of antitrust lawsuits by plaintiffs claiming they were harmed by the rigging of the London interbank offered rate. In more than two dozen interrelated cases before U.S. District Judge Naomi Reice Buchwald in New York, the banks were alleged to have conspired to depress Libor by understating their borrowing costs, thereby lowering their interest expenses on products tied to the rates. While potential damages were estimated to be in the billions of dollars, the judge ruled the cases must be dismissed because of the inability of litigants that included brokerage Charles Schwab Corp. (SCHW), pension funds and other bondholders to show they were harmed. Buchwald, whose March 29 ruling allowed some commodities-manipulations claims to proceed to a trial, said that, while private plaintiffs must show actual harm, her ruling didn’t impede governments from pursuing antitrust claims tied to attempts to manipulate Libor. “We recognize that it might be unexpected that we are dismissing a substantial portion of plaintiffs’ claims, given that several of the defendants here have already paid penalties to government regulatory agencies reaching into the billions of dollars,” Buchwald wrote. “There are many requirements that private plaintiffs must satisfy but which government agencies need not.”
